titleStmt.title: The Dolphins danger and deliuerance being a ship of 220. tunne hauing in her but 36. men and 2. boyes, who were on the 12. of Ianuary 1616. set vpon by 6. men of warre of the Turkes hauing at the least 1500. men in them : who fought with them 5. houres and a halfe, yet to the glory of God and the honor of our English nation, both shippe and goods safely brought vp the Riuer of Thames and deliuered / truely set forth by the appoyntment of M. Edward Nichols, being Maister of the said ship ; with the names of all those that were slaine on the English part, the maner how, and how many were maymed, and what they are that suruiue.
titleStmt.author: Nichols, Edward, fl. 1617.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 26 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 13 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: The Dolphins danger and deliuerance being a ship of 220. tunne hauing in her but 36. men and 2. boyes, who were on the 12. of Ianuary 1616. set vpon by 6. men of warre of the Turkes hauing at the least 1500. men in them : who fought with them 5. houres and a halfe, yet to the glory of God and the honor of our English nation, both shippe and goods safely brought vp the Riuer of Thames and deliuered / truely set forth by the appoyntment of M. Edward Nichols, being Maister of the said ship ; with the names of all those that were slaine on the English part, the maner how, and how many were maymed, and what they are that suruiue.
titleStmt.author: Nichols, Edward, fl. 1617.
Taylor, John, 1580-1653.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Henry Gosson, and are to be solde in Panier Alley,

notesStmt.note: "A toothlesse satire vpon him that made, or rather mard the former booke" signed: Iohn Taylor, p. [5]-[6].

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Dolphins danger: and Deliuerance. Being a Ship of 220. Tunne hauing in her but 36. Men and 2. Boyes, who were on the 12. of Ianuary 1616. ≈øet vpon by 6. Men of Warre of the Turkes hauing at the lea≈øt 1500. Men in them, who fought with them 5. houres and a halfe, yet to the glory of God and the honor of our Engli≈øh Nation, both Shippe and goods ≈øafely brought vp the Riuer of Thames and deliuered. Truely ≈øet forth by the appoyntment of M. Edward Nichols, being Mai≈øter of the ≈øaid Ship. With the names of all tho≈øe that were ≈ølaine on the Engli≈øh part, the maner how, and how many were maymed, and what they are that ≈øuruiue.
LONDON. Printed for Henry Go≈ø≈øon, and are to be ≈øolde in Panier Alley. 1617.

div.head: To the High and mighty Charles Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornewall, Yorke, and Albanie, Earle of Che≈øter, and Knight of the mo≈øt noble order of the Garter.
div.p:
RIGHT Gracious Prince, (I your humble Va≈ø≈øall) beeing imboldened by your innated generous acceptation of all good indeauours, to pre≈øent your Highnes with this poore piece of a ≈øhadow of the ≈øub≈øtantiall perills that I haue e≈øcaped, which for my part had neuer beene publi≈øhed, but that it was fal≈øly printed without my knowledge; which for the regard I haue to the truth and mine owne Credit, I could doe no le≈ø≈øe then contradict with a Refutation of fal≈øhood. I humbly implore
your Highnes to be≈øtow your gracious reading of the infallible verity of the truth, which if you vouch≈øafe, you ≈øhall therein ≈øee Gods power manife≈øted when man is at the weake≈øt. So wi≈øhing your Highnes all earthly and heauenly felicity, I remaine.

closer.signed: Your humble and obedient Seruant. EDWARD NICNOLLS.

div.head: A Toothle≈ø≈øe Satire vpon him that made, or rather mard the former Booke.
div.l: RIch cloath of gold vnto a Botcher brought,
It ≈øhall be mard, not made, quite ≈øham'd, not fram'd:
When wor≈øer ≈øtuffe by a good Worke-man wrought,
Becomes the owner, makes the maker fam'd.
Rare Phi≈øicke, as it is as abus'd, or vs'd,
As is the Doctors ignorance, or skill:
Such operation from it is infus'd,
That it doth helpe, or hurt, or cure, or kill.
Vnto the ≈øtuffe the fault we cannot put,
Nor to the Phi≈øicke, we the crime apply:
The Bungling Taylor ≈øpoyld when he did cut,
And want of skill did cau≈øe the patient dye.
Then let a botching patcher botch and mend,
Let Mountebankes giue Phi≈øicke vnto dogs:
Let Coopers on their hooples Tubs attend,
And Millers deale no further then their Cogges.
For, when a witles Rooke ≈øhall vndertake,
Of ≈øuch exployts as the≈øe to make a Booke:
The ancient Prouethe true, he ≈øeeme to make
God ≈øends good meat, the Diuell ≈øends a Cooke.
Why, ≈øuch a worke as this de≈øerues to haue
A Homers, or a ∆≤irgils skill to grace in
And not an ignorant intruding K----
Who≈øe blindnes did in euery place mi≈øplace it.
Some lies ≈øome truthes together cram'd and thru≈øt,
Quite out of Time, like mu≈øtard after meat:
That 'tis a wonder ≈øuch a fellow dur≈øt
VVith wit ≈øo little, write of things ≈øo great.
VVhere thirty ≈øixe men and two boyes in fight,
Gain≈øt fifteene hundred were ≈øixe houres oppos'd:
Boorded with multitudes; with maine and might,
Round with the foes, and fiery flames inclos'd
Where death was ≈øcorn'd and vallour was belou'd,
Where victory was that, at which they aym'd;
Where noble Re≈øolution was aproou'd
Where Fame adornes, the ≈øound, dead, hurt and maim'd,
What ≈øubiect could a pen more Ample find
(If all were written in perticular)
From Thames, vnto the farthe≈øt ≈øhore of Inde,
Or from the Artick toth' Antartick ≈øtarre.
Why ≈øhould a fellow, beeing there in place,
Remember not him≈øelfe, or any other;
But bury all their glory in di≈øgrace,
And each mans Acts in darke obliuion ≈ømother:
O! tis a hell of hells, and ≈øhame of ≈øhames,
Where men ≈øhall iu≈øtly dare to fight and dye:
And writers will not rege≈øter their names.
When noming makes them liue Immortally.
To ≈øhew how valiant men doe ≈øpend their blood,
It doth each worthy heart with courage ≈øtrike,
To Imitate the actions that are good,
And by example to attemp the like.
But when a man ≈øhall for a certaine know,
That with his life, his memory mu≈øt fall:
And no Records his worthine≈ø≈øe ≈øhall ≈øhow,
The≈øe meanes will make ≈øtarke Cowards of vs all.
Then the≈øe poore lines ≈øhall make the≈øe men ≈øuruiue,
Vnto the vtmo≈øt end of time or fate:
They liu'd and dyed, and dead, are ≈øtill aliue,
In Name, in Pame, in Earthly, Heauenly ≈øtate.
And as for him that writ the Booke before,
Let him write better, or el≈øe write no more.

div.head: The Dolphins danger and Deliuerance: Being a Shippe of London of 220. Tunne, hauing in her but 36. men, and two Boyes.
div.p: THe Almighty Creator, (who onely worketh wonders) confounding ≈øtrong things by weake meanes, as Dauids Sling, Samgars Goad, Samp≈øons Iaw-bone, Gedeons Pitchers, the great Captaine Si≈øera and Holofernes kil'd by two ≈øeely weake Woemen. All the≈øe and innumerable examples more there are both in diuine and humane Hi≈øtories, which demon≈øtrates that victory doth not con≈øi≈øt in the Arme of fle≈øh, but in the omnipotent Lord of Ho≈øts, and God of Battles.

The Con≈øideration of which makes vs with thankefulne≈ø≈øe to commemorate this our great Deliuerance, from ≈øo imminent dangers, and ≈øharpe A≈ø≈øaults, as few, or none hath more cau≈øe to be thankfull for the like, and not to attribute any thing to my ≈øelfe being the Mai≈øter of the Ship, or with o≈øtentation to puffe vp any of my Company, but giuing the glory to whom glory belongs, I proceed.

About the end of this la≈øt yeare, our affaires beeing accompli≈øht at Zant, our Ship called the Dolphin of London, of the burthen of 220. Tunne, hauing in her 19. ca≈øt Pieces, and 5. Murtherers 36. Men and two Boyes, the Mai≈øters name Edward Nichols, a man who≈øe courage, indu≈øtry, knowledge, and integrity, are manife≈øted by his actions in former times, but now more particularly in this la≈øt and perilous aduenture, we being laden weyed our Anchor, and ≈øet ≈øaile from Zant the fir≈øt of Ianuary 1616. with a faire gale of winde at North and by Ea≈øt the 8. of Ianuary, we had ≈øight of the Iland of Sardaine,
then the wind beeing come We≈øterly, wee on the ninth day ≈øtood for Callery, we came clo≈øe by two litle watch Towers, who ≈øhot two ≈øhot neere vs to giue warning to vs, that they would ≈øpeak with vs, which night would not permit, for if wee could haue ≈øent a ≈øhore to them, their intent was to haue informed vs of the Turkes men of war, which after we met withall to our co≈øt and perrill and theirs to, for the≈øe townes were not aboue two Leagues off from the place where wee made our fight. At night (being calme) we ≈øailed towards Cape Pola, which ≈ømall gale brought vs neere to the Cape the 11. day About 2. of the Clock after noone. Three Leagues Ea≈øtward of the afore≈øaid Cape, we de≈øcryed a Satty, which is a ≈ømall coa≈øting Ve≈ø≈øell, ≈øent at that time for a ≈øcout or ≈øpye, belonging to the Turks men of Warr: who kept ‚Ä¢ ight of vs in the euening neere the Ile of Serdine, which belongs to the King of Spaine: The ≈øaid Satty putting forth a light aloft, to giue a ≈øigne to the re≈øt of his a≈ø≈øociates that hee had e≈øpied
vs, and the more to delude vs, they let th ‚Ä¢ light ≈øodainly fall, that we might immagine it to be the ≈øhooting of a Starre.

The 12. of Ianuary in the morning about 4. of the clocke we had better ≈øight of the Sattie, and we perceiued that ≈øhe ≈øtood in to get betwixt the ≈øhore and vs, which made vs doubt ≈øhe had more fellowes not far off, as not long after wee found: the Mr. pre≈øently ≈øent one to the top ma≈øt head who pre≈øently di≈øcouered 5. Ships more making towards vs before the wind being then at we≈øt South we≈øt, which the Mai≈øter with a pro≈øpectiue gla≈ø≈øe perceiu'd to be the Turks men of war. The fir≈øt of them booming by him≈øelfe before the wind with al his ≈øailes abroad, without colours or Flag, yet at pre≈øent boording he put his flag out as we immagined: After him came 2. ≈øhips more of greater burthen then the fir≈øt, and next one more which put his Flag in the main top as we perceiued afterward: then came the 5. and la≈øt much greater in bignes and force then any of the re≈øt, all ≈øtrongly prepared to offend and defend
in any Godles de≈øperate a≈ø≈øault; our M. perceiuing their readines, made ≈øpeedy preparation for the incounter with our Ordinance and ≈ømall ≈øhot, and other defen≈øiue munition, fir≈øt per≈øwading his men with mo≈øt Chri≈øtian and manly Re≈øolution by prayer fir≈øt to recommend their ≈øoules, their bodies, and their actions to their God and Sauiour, which being done they went to dinner, after which the Mr. againe exhorted them in this manner. Contrymen and fellowes, you ≈øee into what an exigent it hath plea≈øed God to ≈øuffer vs to fall into, let vs remember that we are but men, and mu≈øt die of nece≈ø≈øity, when, where and how, is only in Gods knowledge & appointment, but if it be his plea≈øure, that this mu≈øt be the la≈øt of our dayes, his will be done, and let vs for his glory, our ≈øoules welfare, our Countries honor & the credit of our ≈øelues, fight it valiantly to the la≈øt ga≈øpe: let vs prefer a noble death before a ≈ølaui≈øh life, & if we die let vs die to gaine a better life, for mine own part qd. he, I will ≈øee that if we e≈øcape this danger, that if any be hurt & maimd in the fight
they ≈øhall bee carefully prouided for their health and maintenance whil≈øt they liue afterward, therefore bee re≈øolute ≈øtand to it, heere is no ≈øhrinking, but force perforce we mu≈øt be men or ≈ølaues, die with me, or if you will not, I by Gods grace will dye with you.

The≈øe cheerfull words had been ≈øufficient to put courage into faint hartles Cowards: but much more it emboldened vs that were feareles before, for wee all expected greedily to make proofe of the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: at which the Mai≈øter cau≈øed his Trumpets twice to haile them, but they not regarding vs, ≈øcornd to an≈øwer vs, then the M. went vp the poop and waued his ≈øword 3. or 4. times ouer his head, brandi≈øhing it with ≈øuch dreadles re≈øolution, as if the day had beene ours already: then the Trumpets ≈øounded a charge, which warlik noy≈øe in≈øpird vs with new courage, & beeing within ≈øhot of them our Mr. commanded his Gunner to make his leuell & to ≈øhoot, went clo≈øe by his quarter that was neere≈øt vs, ≈øhot on purpo≈øe to mi≈ø≈øe him, as a warning what kind welcome
they were to haue at our hands at which the formo≈øt ≈øhip came vp to vs apace, being almo≈øt becalmed, or with very little winde, returning vs wor≈øe then wee ≈øent for their fir≈øt ≈øhot kild vs a man, ≈øo betwixt vs for a good ≈øpace was a mo≈øt furious encounter, they hauing aduantage of vs by rea≈øon of the winde, pre≈øently layde vs a boord with one of their ≈øhippes, this was neere about eleauen of the clocke, then they ≈øounded their Trumpets, and gaue ≈øueh a ≈øhowt as if they had won the victory already. But God, that neuer leaues tho≈øe that put their confidence in him, cheared our Mai≈øter and Company with ≈øuch manly fortitude, that pre≈øently our Trumpets ≈øounded and an≈øwered them with a charge. (Which Trumpeter was pre≈øently ≈ølaine, as ≈øhalbe after related,) and the Boat≈øwaine winding his whi≈øtle, that pell-mell we fell to it, in ≈øuch feirce manner that their great ordinance had torne our ≈øhippe that wee v≈øed our Gunes cleare of the ports, for they had left vs no port on the quarters but all open,
but we not failing to pay them as well on their bow, to their great di≈ømaying, for we had not left them one man aliue from their maine-ma≈øt forward; be≈øides we di≈ømounted their ordinance, & tore them ≈øo neer the water that their cheife Commanders were forced with their Cuttleaxes to beate their owne men, to force them to make more ha≈øt to vngrapple from vs then they did to boord vs.

All this time the Mai≈øter, Vigillently went to and frow encouraging his men, ≈øometimes in the Gunner roome, ≈øometimes at the healme, ≈øometimes on the port as oca≈øion ≈øerued, and where his pre≈øence was mo≈øt needfull. This fir≈øt fight continued two howers, the ≈øhip was in burden, two hundred tunnes, or there abouts, and had in her 25. peices of ordinance, and about 250. men, the Captaine of her, wee imagine was one Wal≈øingham, which ≈øhould be an Engli≈øh man by that name, and Admirall of him≈øelfe for ≈øo it ≈øignifide by his Flag in his maine top, they boorded vs on
our Larboord quarter, armd with fauchions, hatchets, and halfe pikes, they ≈øtaid aboord vs halfe an hower, tearing vp our naileboords, vpon the poope and the Traphatch, but wee hauing a murtherer in the round hou≈øe kept the larbboord-≈øide cleare, while≈øt our men with the other ordinance, and muskets, and a murtherer in our Traphatch, playd vpon them and their ≈øhip, yet for all this they paide our gallery with ≈ømal ≈øhot that we were much endangered, but at la≈øt we ≈øhot her through and through, and they vs likewi≈øe, that being fearefull to be ≈øunke ≈øhe bore a head from vs and lay by the lee to mend her leakes, this fight was ≈øo neere the ≈øhore, that the inhabitants ≈øet vp a gla≈ø≈øe and found it la≈øted two howers and a halfe, and this was the fir≈øt encounter in which was kild fiue men and a little boy, the manner how they were ≈ølaine ≈øhalbe at the end of the booke.

Now the Second incounter as wee ≈øuppo≈øe was with Captaine Kelleies Ship that
came likewi≈øe vp with his flag in the maine top, and another Ship with his Flag in the fore top, which Shippes were at lea≈øt three hundred tunne apeece or there abouts, and had in each of them twenty eight or thirty peeces of Ordinance, and about two hundred & fifty men, ≈øo they laid vs aboard on the Starbord quarter, and the other on the Larbor, where entring our ≈øhip thicke and threefold, with their ≈øemiters, hatchets, halfe pikes and other weapons, put vs in great danger both of the lo≈ø≈øe of our Ship and our liues, for they performed much man-hood and many dangerous hazards, among≈øt which there was one of their company, that de≈øperately went vp into our maine top to fetch downe our Flag, which being ≈øpied by the Steward of our Ship, pre≈øently ≈øhot him with his Mu≈øquet that hee fell tumbling vpon our decke, and pre≈øently Ca≈øt ouerbord by their owne men, as they did the re≈øt, leauing the Flag hehind him, ≈øo the≈øe two ≈øhippes fought with vs with great re≈øolution, playing vppon vs
with their Ordinance and ≈ømall ≈øhot, for the ≈øpace of an hower and a halfe, of whom we receiued ≈øome hurt, and likewi≈øe they of vs, but when they could not preuaile, nor any way make vs to yeeld, they bore vp and pa≈ø≈øed from vs to lay their ≈øhips by the leeto ≈øtop their leaks, for wee had grieuou≈øly batterred them with our great Ordinance, and this was the ≈øecond attempt they made vpon vs.

Now for the third, there came one more of theirs ≈øhips of two hundred tunne that had 30. pieces of Ordinance, and at the lea≈øt two hundred and 50. men all well prouided as might be, which was as we thought too great a number for vs, beeing ≈øo few in our ≈øhip, but God that was our friend gaue vs ≈øuch ≈øtrength and ≈øucce≈ø≈øe that they little preuailed again≈øt vs, for at their fir≈øt comming vp, notwith≈øtanding all their multitude of men, wee ≈øhot her quite thorough and thorough, we entertaind her with two minion and three ≈øacre, on our ≈øtarboard ≈øide, then ≈øhe fell to our Larboard
≈øide, and then we welcom'd her with a ≈øacre in our bow, two minion and, one demiculuerin, which made her for≈øake vs and lye by the lee, as the others did before: but the other ≈øhip remaining, greater then the re≈øt, in burden 500. tunnes with 650. men, laid vs aboard on the Starbord ≈øide, and in that quarter they entred our ≈øhip, with their Semiters, Fauchions, halfe Pikes, and other weapons, running to and fro vpon the deck crying ≈øtill in the Turki≈øh tongue, and ≈øome Engli≈øh, yeeld your ≈øelues, promi≈øing we ≈øhould be well v≈øed, and one third part of our goods deliuered backe, with ≈øuch like faire promi≈øes; at which one of our company told, the Mai≈øter of the large offer of the Turkes, per≈øwading him to yeeld, but the Mai≈øter replied, away villaine, I will neuer giue them part or quarter, whil≈øt I haue quarters to my body. Who beeing thus re≈øolued, ≈øome of our men plyed our Ordinance again≈øt them, ≈øome played with the ≈ømall ≈øhot, ≈øome with other weapons, as ≈øwords and halfe Pikes and ≈øuch like, in
midde≈øt of which skirmi≈øh, it ≈øo happened by ill chance that they ≈øeeing that we would not yeeld to compo≈øition firde our ≈øhip in three places in the Mai≈øters Cabbin, the gallery, with wild fire balls ca≈øt into the hold and ≈øo left vs, be≈øides our gunnes and theirs fired the Carpenters cabbin, that wee and the ≈øhip was fired, and in great danger to be lo≈øt and ca≈øt away, had not the Lord in his mercy pre≈øerued vs, and ≈øent vs meanes happily to quench it, but now marke the accident, the fier being perceiued by our enemies to burne outragiou≈øly, and thinking that our Shippe would haue therewith beene ≈øodainly burned to the water, they left vs to our fortunes, falling a ≈øterne from vs, and ≈øo wee put to the ≈øhoare vnder a Towre, for ≈øome ≈øuccour, where wee let an Anchor fall thinking to ride there all that night, which wee had no ≈øooner done, but we ≈øaw the great ≈øhip that parted from vs, in our iudgement beare vpon vs, and at that time the ≈øhip that neuer boorded vs ≈øhot a peece of ordinance, while wee were
preparing for another incounter and ≈øo we were forced to wey our Anchor, and ≈øet ≈øayle to get better ≈øuccour, and the enemy being weary of our company hoy≈øt out their boates to mend their leakes, wherevpon we put into the roade betweene the two little towers, where wee ≈øent our maymed gunner a ≈øhore to one of tho≈øe towers, to make ≈øhot at the enemy if need were, where we lay fiue daies, mending the brui≈øes and leakes of our ≈øhip: the lo≈ø≈øes we receiued in the afore≈øaide fight, were ≈øixe Men and one Boy, which were killed outright, and there were hurt eyght men and one Boy more: but the Lord doth know what damage we put them to, and what number wee ≈ølew in their ≈øhips.

There is one thing more worthy of remeÃÑberance of our Chirurgion who≈øe name was Robert Groue, who as hee was dre≈ø≈øing one of our men in the hold of our Ship, a Ball of Wildfire fell into his Ba≈øon which he thinking to ca≈øt ouer boord it fell vpon the decke, which had greatly indangered
vs but that hee re≈øolutly fell vpon it and rouling in it ≈ømothered it out with his body. The Turkes trumpeters were aboard and ≈øounded their Trumpets, yet notwith≈øtanding, our men a≈ø≈øaulted them ≈øo fiercely, that they forced them off, and the Bo≈øwaine (≈øeeing them flye) mo≈øt vndantedly with a whi≈øtle blourd them to the skirmi≈øh, if ≈øo they dur≈øt. The Captaines of three of their Ships were Engli≈øhmen, as we thinke, who tooke part with the Turks thus to rob and ≈øpoyle vpon the Ocean, their names were Wal≈øingham, Kelley, and Samp≈øon.

Vpon the 13. of Ianuary there came aboard certaine Spaniards in the morning betimes to witnes what hurts wee had receiued, who ≈øeing our men dead, went a ≈øhore with vs, and ≈øhowed vs where wee might bury them, but as wee wore bu≈øie in making their graues, and couering the bodies with earth, there came ≈øayling by a Flemi≈øh Ship of twelue≈øcore tunne, which the enemy in the darke thought had beene vs,
and ≈øo let her pa≈ø≈øe, which had in her fiue or ≈øixe thou≈øand pounds, which had beene cha≈øed with tho≈øe men of warre that had fought with vs before, all which mony they brought in a long boate to this ≈øhore, and left in the ≈øhip onely three men, which were two Saylers and one Soldier, that afterwards within two daies brought the ≈øaid ≈øhip into the Road of Callery, not any thing at all indangered, God be prai≈øed.

Vpon the 15. of the ≈øame Month when we came from the burying of our men, & had re≈øted our ≈øelues in our Shippe ≈øome two or 3. houres, as God would haue it, the wind began to blow a ≈øtrong gale, and by little & little grew to be a terrible tempe≈øt, through which from Sunday night till Friday in the euening. wee lay in ≈øuch extremity of weather, as raine, winde, lightening and thunder, that we thought we ≈øhould neuer haue got cleere from the Road where we lay: during which ≈øtorme and tempe≈øt there dyed one of our men, that had beene hurt in the fight, who≈øe body weca≈øt ouerbord, into the
Sea, without any other buriall, and ≈øo when the winde and ≈øea a little calmed, wee ≈øet vp ≈øaile and came forward: but within three dayes after we buried 3. men more in the ≈øea, and the ≈øame afternoone we arriued in the Road of Callery, and lay at anchor, where againe ≈øearching our Ship, we found it rent and torne in many ≈øeueral places, ≈øo in Callery we mended our Ship, and hired certaine men there to help vs to ≈øtop her leakes, and fi≈øh her Ma≈øts, and hauing all thinges fitting for our Voyage homewards, vpon the 30. day of Ianuary we committed our ≈øelues againe vnto the Sea, ≈øo leauing Callery wee came foreward with a Frenchman, who was bound to a place Ore≈øtone, ≈øome thirty Leagues from Callery, where after two daies we left his company being the fir≈øt day of February, and after that putting forewards ≈øtill towards England, we are now by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance ≈øafely ariued at London, to the contentation of our Owners, and the comfort of our ≈øelues that (by the Almighties protection) haue e≈øcaped ≈øo many dangers. God be prai≈øed.

list.item: WAlter Penro≈øe, the fir≈øt man kild, being ≈øhot in the belly.
2 Thomas Sheapheard quarter mai≈øter, his head ≈øhot off.

3 William Sw ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ te, Trumpetter, as he ≈øounded in the fight had one arme ≈øhot off, yet he ≈øounded till another great ≈øhot ≈øtroke off his other arme, with his Trumpet and all, then after hee was kild with a ≈øhot thorow the body.
4 William Ra≈ø≈øell, quarter mai≈øter, had me arme fir≈øt ≈øhot off, afterward he was ≈øhot through and kild.
5 Iohn Sands, the crowne of his head ≈øhot off.
6 Beniamin Cornellius, a boy, ≈øhot in the throat, kild.
7 Dauid Fau≈øe, mai≈øters mate, ≈øhot in the groyne, kild.

p.hi: The≈øe men were kild outright and buries a ≈øhore.
The≈øe 4 men dyed within 4 or 5 dayes, after were cast into the ≈øea.

list.item: 8 Io: Blackatar, quarter Mr. his leg maym'd & burnt blind, yet he labored to quench the ≈øhip beeing fired.
9 Thomas Worger, a youth, the Ma≈øters ≈øeruant, his ≈øholder blade ≈øhot off and liued three dayes.

10 William Iames, Trumpetter, burnd with wilde fire, that he flamed like a fiery man all ouer, then Iohn Roff Pur≈øer ca≈øt water on him, to quench him, he liued 5 dayes in great paine: in the fight an arrow came betwixt the Mai≈øters legs at the helme and ran into the ≈øaid Iames his leg which the Mai≈øterpuld out.
11 Iohn Pre≈øtin, a youth, kild with a musket.

p.hi: The≈øe following, were maymd and hurt, and are liuing.

list.item: Robert May Mai≈øters mate, ≈øhot in the thigh,
Tho Wright, gunner, with ≈øhot & ≈øplintars hurt in 12. places.
Thomas Dauiell, burnt with powder, and lo≈øt an eye.
Roger Gi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ er, wounded in the head with ≈øplinters.
Robert Downes, the Mai≈øters boy, ≈øhot in the belly, liues.

Edward Nichols Ma≈øter, ≈øhot with a ≈ømall ≈øhot, that tore his ho≈øe and ≈øtockings through, and gaue his legge a ≈øcarre, and 4 times ≈øhot through the ho≈øe. Fra. Con≈øtable Boat ≈øwaine, Iohn Ro ‚Ä¢ he Pur≈øer. William Lucas Carpenter. The. Hob Gunners mate, Wil. Moore quarter Gunner. Wil. Coll ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
Steward Rob. Grone Chirurgion. Iohn Adiney Couper. Chri≈øto. Au≈øten Cock≈øon. Hum ‚Ä¢ . Lee, Boat≈øons mate. Wil. Renfree quar: M. Will. Chalicom, I≈øake Watlington, Trumperters. Thee: Ander≈øon, Tho. Spurden Nicho. Wilkin≈øon, Henry Low, Cornelius Scot, Philip a welchman, Saylers the re≈øt were pa≈ø≈øengers.
